data.body:

Default setting could be 24 hours or 1 week.

data.title: Atom should use standard directories correctly on Linux and Windows
data.body:
(updated 14 aug 2015)
## On Linux

XDG Base Directory Specification defines standard paths inside $HOME folders that should be used by applications. Unfortunately, Atom creates directory "~/.atom" and puts part of data into it. Another part correctly placed at "~/.config/atom". Directory "~/.cache/atom" created, but seems to stay unused.
- Atom should not either create "~/.atom" or use it
- Atom should use "~/.config/atom" for all configuration files
- Atom should use "~/.local/share/atom" for all intermediate data and downloaded packages
- Atom should use "~/.cache/atom" for all cache and intermediate data that can be deleted without breaking user's work
- Lowercase version of application name used in paths - "atom" instead of "Atom"
## On Windows

Atom creates .atom directory in user's home folder - it's absolutely wrong behaviour since most Windows apps don't and shouldn't create anything in user folder.
- Atom should not either create "C:\Users\%USERNAME%.atom" or use it
- Atom should use "C:\Users\%USERNAME%\AppData\Roaming\Atom" for all configuration files; Roaming used to allow standard way of synchronization between user's devices
- Atom should use "C:\Users\%USERNAME%\AppData\Local\Atom" for all intermediate data and downloaded packages
- Atom should use "C:\Users\%USERNAME%\AppData\Local\Atom\cache" for all cache and intermediate data that can be deleted without breaking user's work
  Note that Windows can be installed on drive "D:\", so "C:\Users" used as example.
## More information on standard paths

For more information see tables for Windows and Linux at http://doc.qt.io/qt-5/qstandardpaths.html
You can search at this page by words:
- DataLocation
- CacheLocation
- ConfigLocation

data.title: Having both "Exclude VCS Ignored Paths" and "Hide VCS Ignored Paths" settings is confusing
data.body:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/753919/9144836/8b9fc460-3d04-11e5-8a93-7f1e4a62c348.png)

The _Exclude VCS Ignored Paths_ setting under Core Settings commonly gets confused with the similar setting under the Tree View package, _Hide VCS Ignored Paths_. I believe the first is for excluding files from search and the latter is for the tree view itself. 

For an idealized UI I'd vote for removing both settings and adding a new one that is a Select box where we can select to _exclude_ (from search and tree view), _exclude from search only_, and _show_. It doesn't make sense (to me) to allow not showing in the tree view but showing up in search.

We could also just add some explanation text to both settings if the above is too radical a change.

// ref #8270

data.title: Feature request: cloud-stored editor configurations
data.body:
I use Atom on multiple computers and VMs.  It'd be great if my package installations and configuration settings could be stored in one spot and applied to multiple atom installations.  I'm thinking of this like sync'd browser bookmarks being stored in the cloud.

The feature should be optional, but if implemented like Google does with Chrome, I could imagine creating different profiles with different settings (as a more advanced implementation).  In a simpler implementation, I'd get one profile on the cloud and could simply decide in a given installation whether or not I wanted it to use the stored settings.

data.title: Scrollbar can stay active even if mouse button is relesed
data.body:
Using Atom 1.0.5 on Windows 7 64-bit.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Click and hold on the dragging thing on the scroll bar with the left mouse button (like when you are scrolling).
2. While continuing to hold the button, move your mouse out towards the center of the screen (away from the scroll bar's area).
3. Click and release the middle mouse button (the scroll wheel button).
4. Let go of the left mouse button.

What happens:
- The icon of the scroll bar stays as a square (rather than the small rounded style) like when you click and hold on it.
- If you move your mouse back to the scroll bar, the scroll bar's position will follow your mouse, even when no buttons are pressed.

Clicking on the scroll bar again fixes the issue.

data.body:
Okay, so guys. People have been commenting on less-autocompile about it not being able to compile .less that uses javascript. It seems y'all did something to break the global.Function on 1.0.5. Anything lower than 1.0.5 works just fine.

In less-autocompile I use loophole on the global.Function such as:

```
var oldFunction = global.Function;
global.Function = loophole.Function;
.... //do stuff here while replaced
global.Function = oldFunction; //restore to default global
```

However, this does not appear to work in Atom 1.0.5. At least, it used to affect the less compiler parse Function, but it doesn't appear to anymore. I have proven that it is indeed 1.0.5 causing this issue again. I was on Atom 1.0.4 and lower for awhile and it still worked. The minute I updated to 1.0.5 it no longer works.

data.title: Cannot easily specify variable Tab Length
data.body:
Why does Atom feel the need to choose which tab lengths I'm allowed to use? So many other editors let you specify this value (XCode/ST2/ST3/TW/KE/VisualStudio/even Word). And it's useful for all kinds of random tasks: sometimes I need to view/edit a massive variable-length TSV, so, elsewhere, I just throw my tab length to 40/60/whatever and edit faster than Excel thanks to regexes and [column selection](#2306).

The Tab Length item in the Settings panel should be a field, like Font Size, Line Height, and every other reasonable option: not a dropdown.

data.title: Window decorations corrupted by workspace switching on XFCE
data.body:
When I switch workspaces on XFCE 4.10 the Atom window decorations go all glitchy.
### Software
- Linux Mint XFCE 17.1
- XFCE 4.10
- Atom 1.0.3
- Firefox 39 (other GTK apps work too)
### Steps to Reproduce
- Open Atom in one workspace and something else in another (Firefox for example). 
- Switch from the Atom workspace to the other workspace and back.
### Result

Atom's window decorations aren't rendered, rather the contents of the other workspace are shown in their place. It looks like Atom needs to redraw. Switching focus to another application in the same workspace returns Atom to normal. No messages or errors are shown in the terminal used to launch Atom.

Here's a video of this behaviour: http://sproul.xyz/atom-xfce-render-bug.ogg

This doesn't happen on my Arch Linux machine (with XFCE 4.12) so it could well be a bug in this slightly old XFCE version. I'll try to upgrade it and update this thread accordingly.

Related but distinct from #3593 (which I can also reproduce).
